Some examples of software not distributed by Ubuntu include:
â
* Software that enables the playback of [[regional lockout|region-locked]]<ref>The library is needed even when watching a DVD in the target region </ref> video [[DVD]]s, due to the questionable legal status of the [[Libdvdcss]] open-source DVD-decoding library in some parts of the world. Libdvdcss, as well as much other software that might be forbidden in certain parts of the world, is readily available for Ubuntu through [[Medibuntu]].
+
==Availability of proprietary software==
  +
{{further|[[Linux distribution#Proprietary software]]}}
  +
Ubuntu has a certification system for third party software.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://ubuntu.com/partners/certification/software | title=partners/certification/software | accessdate=2006-03-16}}</ref> Ubuntu-certified proprietary software should work well in Ubuntu. However, many programs familiar to users of non-free operating systems, such as [[Microsoft Windows]], are incompatible and are not Ubuntu-certified. Some proprietary software that does not limit distribution is included in Ubuntu's ''multiverse'' component.
  +   +
Some examples of software not distributed by Ubuntu, but that can be easily installed:
  +   +
* Software that enables the playback of [[regional lockout|region-locked]]<ref>The library is needed even when watching a DVD in the target region </ref> video [[DVD]]s, due to the questionable legal status of the [[Libdvdcss]] open-source DVD-decoding library in some parts of the world. Libdvdcss, as well as much other software that might be forbidden in certain parts of the world, is readily available for Ubuntu through the package [[ubuntu-restricted-extras]].
* Some popular proprietary web-browser plugins, such as [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]]'s (formerly [[Macromedia]]'s) [[Adobe Flash|Flash]]. One [[workaround]] to the specific prohibition against redistribution in the Flash [[EULA]] is the multiverse package "flashplugin-nonfree" which automatically downloads the Linux Flash plugin directly from Adobe's site and then installs it.
* Some popular proprietary web-browser plugins, such as [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]]'s (formerly [[Macromedia]]'s) [[Adobe Flash|Flash]]. One [[workaround]] to the specific prohibition against redistribution in the Flash [[EULA]] is the multiverse package "flashplugin-nonfree" which automatically downloads the Linux Flash plugin directly from Adobe's site and then installs it.
